pages.transcription:
Mrs S.F. Orton
250. W. Rundolph St.

Thursday, January 1, 1874
New Year's Day.
Remarkable weather - mild and pleasant.
We received 13 New Year's calls.
Another year has passed away
Another year comes in today.

Sunday, January 4, 1874
1st Sabbath of the new year.
Our snow storm prevented me from going to church
My verse for to-day is=
"As many as I love, I rebuke &
chasten; be zealous, therefore & repent."
Bible.
Monday, 5
Cold.
Della begins school again
to-day. Put away my old Diary.
-many are the memories connected
with it - both sweet & sad.
Rec'd a letter from New-York,
which affords me another chance
to write.
Tuesday, 6
Still cold;
This is the Christian's
week of prayer. Mr poor heart
would vain profit by it.

Wednesday, January 7, 1874.
Still and pleasant.
Copied and altered
one of my old hymns. I am much
intrested in my library book.
"Barriers burned away"
Mother attended church in the evening
Thursday, 8
This has been a pleasant day
Winter soon will pass away
Wrote my new hymn.
"Glad Tidings"
This is my first new hymn for the
New year. 
Friday, 9
More Snow:
Received an intresting
letter from Aunt Lucy
Finished my library book
I think it is a great story.
My year at the library expires Sunday

Saturday, January 10, 1874.
Clear & pleasent
Our week of prayer is ended - may its reviving spirit continue.
Did a little copying, but much thinking.
Think I shall get out to Church to-morrow.
Della had her new kids.
Sunday, 11
This has been a cold Sabbath, - keen winds, but pleasent skies.
Attended the Temple Church, - heard sweet music & good words.
My verse for to-day is,
"Get setteth He the poor on high from affliction"
Psalms.
Monday, 12
Quite mild again.
Did my usual amount of thinking & writing. Hope to be able to attend one of our prayer meetings this week.
Mother not feeling quite as well as usual.

Tuesday, January 13, 1874.
Mild weather - A stormy evening -
My two hymns all ready to send away - think I will get them off Thursday - 
Mother went over to the library for me Lillie had company in the evening -
Wednesday, 14
A very cold day
For the want of a better item I quote these old sayings.
"God helps those who help themselves"
"Truth like roses have thorns about them"
Thursday, 15
"The sky was blue the sun was seen. But winter's winds were sharp and keen."
Did not send my hymns away - I did my usual writing.
Mother had two calls - Church - members -

Friday, January 16, 1874
Weather, - quite mild.
Finished my book, - "Witnessing for Jesus" Think Mrs Orton might write a similar word.
One year ago to-night our beautiful Church was in ruins.
I shall soon have six efforts out.
Saturday, 17
"Winter's cold winds are blowing, But wintery days are going -"
Wrote a letter. Have not recieved anything this week.
Wish I was going to church to-morrow - even where I went last Sabbath.
Sunday, 18
A stormy Sabbath, snow & rain, Did not go out of course. Tried to spend the day as a Christian should.
This is my verse for to=day=
"Lo, I am with you always, even unto the end of the world"
Jesus

Monday, January 19, 1874.
Mild weather - more snow.
Wrote a business letter - received a postal-card from P.P.
Bliss.
This seems to tell me I shall have something more before the week is out.
Tuesday, 20
Stormy weather:-
The fall snow was seen to=day Over the streets and far away.
Sent my three hymns away this morning. Della brought me a new paper The "Temple Calls."
Wednesday, 21
Rain - rain - rain.
Commenced a long letter to Aunt Lucy.
Read a sermon by Pro: David Swing. in The Alliance, found it rich in thought and sentiment

Thursday, January 22, 1874.
Stormy weather. 
"it rains - it rains!"
Did a little writing - On Saturday,
the 24th Old Time grants me again
the yearly gift of a birth-day -
Friday, 23
"After the storm="
Clear & pleasant.
Commenced reading the "Martyrs
of Spain"." - Mrs Orton's gift.
I except to find
the book very interesting.
Saturday, 24
Clear & cold
My 31st birthday.
Wrote a few lines on this
event This is the first time I have
ever written anything of this kind.
Dont think I have succeeded
very well.
Not going to Church to-morrow

Sunday, January 25, 1874.
A pleasant Sabbath.
They all went to
church except me. Miss Riply
sent me some reading matter by
Della - I copy to-day -
"Call upon me
in the day of trouble and I will
deliver thee." - Bible -
Monday, 26
Clear and pleasant.
Received a postal
message from New. York -
Wrote a little poem
for Della - "Our Welcome" -
Father and 
mother attended church in the evening.
Tuesday, 27
Another rainy day.
Received a letter from
Cousin Emeline, and finished my long
letter to Aunt Lucy.
To-day I finished
the book of Romans.
I never read it
with so much interest.

Wednesday, January 28, 1874.
Weather - clear & pleasant.
Did some copying for Della,
which pleased her very much. Her home
entertainment was a pleasant affair. Mother
had a handsome shell given to her
Father came home from Church. evidently
feeling as he has not felt for
long years.
Thursday, 29
Mild weather.
This is the last week of January.
Wrote a message, & did a little
Copying - Wish I could put my thoughts
to another new hymn. Suppose I shall
in due time.
To-day I commenced reading
the 2nd book of Corinthians.
Friday, 30
Stormy weather.
"The falling snow was seen again,
For Winter still hold forth its reign"
Wrote a message & busied myself over
Della's S.S. lesson, for next
Sabbath.

Saturday, January 31, 1874.
Stormy weather.
One of the new year's months has gone.
For time is softly stealing on.
My mail matter
for the past month is rather small
Four-cards - three letters. Della
did a little shopping for me in the
evening.
Sunday, February 1
A pleasant Sabbath.
Snow storm at night.
I copy the golden text.
"To-day, if ye will hear his voice,
harden not your hearts."
Monday, 2
Mild and pleasant.
More sleighing
Wrote a business letter -
The wish that
I noted last Thursday has been granted
for to-day I wrote a new effort which
I call - Mr Petition.

Tuesday, February 3, 1874.
Weather=
Another snow-storm.
Commenced a letter to Cousin
Emeline. My chapter this morning
was the 4ch of Corinthians. Other
Christians know what a good chapter
it is.
How impressive are its closing
verses.
Wednesday, 4
Weather - a mild day; but
a cold night, Finished the letter
that I commenced yesterday.
Miss Nettie Clark brought me a
"prose collection," - called "A beautiful
thought" Father and Mother attended
church in the evening.

Friday, February 6, 1874
Snowy weather.
From early day till day was gone.
The flakes of snow came drifting down
Read Longfellow's Evangeline. So many
know, 'tis a sad, swee story. Poetically
told and yet destitute of poetical rhyme
Saturday, 7
Mild and pleasant.
After the storm.
Have not had a letter this week.
I am afraid it will be a long while
before I shall get to church again.
unclear and temperance and Repose
Slam the door on the doctor's unclear
Longfellow.
Sunday, 8
A mild Sabbath.
I copy today -
O, that never would praise the
Lord for his goodness and for his
wonderful words to the children
of men.
Bible.

Thursday February 12, 1874
Cloudy weather.
My chapter this morning was the 7th of 2nd Corinthians.
Busied myself in getting out Della's S.S. Lesson for the approaching Sabbath.
Friday, 13 (1874)
Pleasant weather.
An eventful day for me.  Received a letter from Mr. Lowry.  He sent me a Post Office order for $12.00.
This is the largest sum that I have ever had at one time.
Saturday, 14 (1874)
Weather. Bright and clear.
St. Valentine's Day.
Father went down and drew my money for me.  Bought mother a pair of kid gloves.  How glad I am that I can help those whom I love.
Received a call from Mrs. Orton.

Sunday, February 15, 1874
A beautiful Sabbath.
The dedication of the 1st Congregational Church took place this morning. I copy today -
"I will instruct the and teach thee in the way which thou shalt go; I will guide thee with mine eye."
Psalms.
Monday, 16 (1874)
The weather mild - the sunshine bright.
For winter soon will take its flight.
Father made arrangements for a seat in the 1st Church.  I hope we may all enjoy it during the coming year.
More reading matter from Della.
Tuesday, 17 (1874)
Weather - pleasant but cold.
Wrote a postal message and also a business letter.
Read a little, thought much.
For my daily life is such.

Sunday, May 10, 1874.
A warm, pleasant Sabbath.
Father took me to evening
service at the Temple Church. Hear at
a good sermon from this text:
"Wherefore the law was our school master to
bring us to Christ that we might be justified
by faith."
Mother & Della still on the
sick list.
Monday, 11
Cloud, weather.
With signs of rain.
Felt quite unwell all day. Did not
write any-much as I wanted to.
Tuesday, 12
Pleasant weather.
"One year ago to-day.
Was Sister Lillie's bridal night."
Wrote my new S.S. hymn - noted last
Thursday. I call it,
"Battling for the Lord"
